title: Subdomain takeover of v.zego.com
content:
Summary
v.zego.com points to an AWS EC2 instance at 52.214.138.192 that no longer exists. I was able to take control of this IP address and run my own EC2 instance. I can now serve content on this domain, obtain a TLS certificate for this domain, etc.
If any customers or servers are pointing to anything within this domain, I could serve them arbitrary/malicious content. I could also use this in case your domain whitelists your own domain for OAuth, or if there are cookies scoped to the entire domain. Usually this can have a high impact.
PoC
Code 84 Bytes
1% dig +short v.zego.com
252.214.138.192
3
4% curl v.zego.com
5<!-- hackerone.com/ian -->
Impact
Subdomain takeover
weaknesses: Externally Controlled Reference to a Resource in Another Sphere
steps: Use dig command to check DNS records for v.zego.com: dig +short v.zego.com
Attempt to access the domain via curl: curl v.zego.com
vuln_description: The subdomain v.zego.com was pointing to an AWS EC2 instance that no longer exists. The researcher was able to take control of the IP address and serve content on this domain, potentially allowing malicious content to be served to users or systems that rely on this domain.
reason: The vulnerability involves a straightforward DNS check and verification of domain ownership through AWS EC2 instance control. There are no complex interactions or novel logic required; it's a common subdomain takeover scenario.
